summary: This is a December 6, 2018, internal update from the Public Corruption Unit, likely within the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (SDNY). It outlines the significant development of a new investigation into Jeffrey Epstein, focusing on allegations of sexual abuse of minors transported to/from New York, and the potential limitations of a 2008 Non-Prosecution Agreement from Florida.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central subject of the new federal investigation for allegedly sexually abusing dozens of minors over more than a decade, including those transported to/from New York. Previously resolved a 2008 federal investigation in Florida with a Non-Prosecution Agreement.

events.title: Florida Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA)
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein resolved a then-pending federal investigation by the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida by entering into a Non-Prosecution Agreement. This agreement purported to immunize Epstein and alleged co-conspirators, including a New York-based 'booker'.

events.title: SDNY Public Corruption Unit Case Update
events.description: The Public Corruption Unit provides an internal update, noting the active investigation into Jeffrey Epstein for sexual abuse of minors, including reviewing documents from the original Florida investigation and identifying New York-based victims.

keyFacts: A new federal investigation into Jeffrey Epstein was active as of December 2018, led by the referenced office (likely SDNY) and the FBI, concerning allegations of sexual abuse of dozens of minors over more than a decade.
The investigation specifically involved minors who were transported to and from New York for the purpose of sexual abuse.

The 2008 Florida Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) was noted as binding only the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida, implying it may not bar prosecution in other jurisdictions like New York.
The Florida NPA purportedly immunized not just Epstein but also alleged co-conspirators, including a New York-based 'booker' responsible for scheduling 'massages' with underage girls.
Investigators were reviewing documents from the original Florida investigation and beginning to identify victims based in New York, with plans to look into post-NPA misconduct allegations.
